unnormalised: **My Journey Through Pregnancy: A Mix of Joy and Jitters**
normalised: My Journey Through Pregnancy: A Mix of Joy and Jitters

unnormalised: So, I found out I was pregnant on 14/02/2024, Valentine's Day! A bit cliche, I know, but it was the best Valentine's gift ever. Dr. Meera Patel at Cloudnine Hospital confirmed it. I was around 6 weeks along, according to her, which was both exciting and terrifying.
normalised: So, I found out I was pregnant on fourteenth February two thousand and twenty four, Valentine's Day! A bit cliche, I know, but it was the best Valentine's gift ever. Doctor Meera Patel at Cloudnine Hospital confirmed it. I was around six weeks along, according to her, which was both exciting and terrifying.

unnormalised: The first trimester? Let's just say morning sickness wasn't just a "morning" thing. It was more like all-day sickness! Ginger chai became my best friend. The gynaecologist, Dr. Patel, prescribed Doxinate for the nausea, but honestly, nothing seemed to help completely. I’d lost around 2 kg, which worried my mom a lot, but the doc said it was normal.
normalised: The first trimester? Let's just say morning sickness wasn't just a "morning" thing. It was more like all-day sickness! Ginger chai became my best friend. The gynaecologist, Doctor Patel, prescribed Doxinate for the nausea, but honestly, nothing seemed to help completely. I’d lost around two kilogram, which worried my mom a lot, but the doc said it was normal.

unnormalised: Around the 12th week, after what felt like a lifetime, things started to settle down a bit. The NIPT scan came back clear (Alhamdulillah!), and we found out we were having a baby girl! My husband, Rohan, was over the moon. We celebrated with a small family dinner.
normalised: Around the twelfth week, after what felt like a lifetime, things started to settle down a bit. The N-I-P-T scan came back clear (Alhamdulillah!), and we found out we were having a baby girl! My husband, Rohan, was over the moon. We celebrated with a small family dinner.

unnormalised: The second trimester was relatively smooth sailing. I started feeling the baby's movements around 18 weeks. Like little butterflies fluttering in my tummy. I began researching baby names and started nesting – organizing everything from the nursery to tiny little socks. I visited Dr. Sharma at AIIMS for a second opinion, just to be sure everything was going according to plan. She reassured me that the baby and I were both healthy.
normalised: The second trimester was relatively smooth sailing. I started feeling the baby's movements around eighteen weeks. Like little butterflies fluttering in my tummy. I began researching baby names and started nesting – organizing everything from the nursery to tiny little socks. I visited Doctor Sharma at A-I-I-M-S for a second opinion, just to be sure everything was going according to plan. She reassured me that the baby and I were both healthy.

unnormalised: Then came the glucose tolerance test. Let's just say I wasn't thrilled about drinking that super sweet concoction. Thankfully, the results were normal. Dr. Patel emphasized the importance of a balanced diet and prescribed some prenatal vitamins. I made sure to incorporate lots of leafy greens and fresh fruits.
normalised: Then came the glucose tolerance test. Let's just say I wasn't thrilled about drinking that super sweet concoction. Thankfully, the results were normal. Doctor Patel emphasized the importance of a balanced diet and prescribed some prenatal vitamins. I made sure to incorporate lots of leafy greens and fresh fruits.

unnormalised: As I entered the third trimester, things started getting real. Braxton Hicks contractions became frequent. Sleepless nights were the norm. The weight gain was definitely showing – I’d put on approximately 10 kgs! I started attending prenatal classes at the hospital, learning about labour, delivery, and newborn care. One of the nurses, Sister Mary, was especially helpful, providing tips on breastfeeding and babywearing.
normalised: As I entered the third trimester, things started getting real. Braxton Hicks contractions became frequent. Sleepless nights were the norm. The weight gain was definitely showing – I’d put on approximately ten kilograms! I started attending prenatal classes at the hospital, learning about labour, delivery, and newborn care. One of the nurses, Sister Mary, was especially helpful, providing tips on breastfeeding and babywearing.

unnormalised: The last few weeks were a mix of excitement and exhaustion. I preponed my work deadlines and started preparing my hospital bag. My due date was 15/09/2024, but babies, as they say, arrive on their own schedule.
normalised: The last few weeks were a mix of excitement and exhaustion. I preponed my work deadlines and started preparing my hospital bag. My due date was fifteenth September two thousand and twenty four, but babies, as they say, arrive on their own schedule.

unnormalised: Finally, on 10/09/2024, at around 3:00 AM, my water broke! It was a mad dash to the hospital. After 12 hrs of labour, our little princess, Aanya, was born at 3.2 kg. The moment I held her in my arms, all the pain and discomfort of the past nine months faded away. It was the most beautiful moment of my life. The journey, though challenging at times, was worth every single second. I wouldn't trade it for the world.
normalised: Finally, on tenth September two thousand and twenty four, at around three zero zero A-M, my water broke! It was a mad dash to the hospital. After twelve hours of labour, our little princess, Aanya, was born at three point two kilogram. The moment I held her in my arms, all the pain and discomfort of the past nine months faded away. It was the most beautiful moment of my life. The journey, though challenging at times, was worth every single second. I wouldn't trade it for the world.
